column6:
<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Blog post about government scientists under attack
username_0: 
<issue_comment>username_1: I dislike this as much or more than you, but our blog is not the the place for this, please reserve this kind of position for your personal blog.
<issue_comment>username_0: I believe an overwhelming majority of our instructors would support us taking some sort of public stand on suppression of science.
<issue_comment>username_2: Given this is an issue related to the overall vision of SWC, and therefore a strategic decision, I'd be interested to hear what the other members of the Steering Committee have to say: @username_6 @JasonJWilliamsNY @weaverbel @username_5 @username_4 @username_3
<issue_comment>username_1: Under 501(c)3 rules we have to be VERY careful about anything like endorsements/criticisms of candidates in political elections in the USA. Without an expert on staff about these kinds of things this is best left up to personal opinion and not official opinions of the organization. Crappy but true. We really don't want to go there at the size we are as an organization. Most of this has to do with candidacy, but the political reality is our fiscal sponsor is a 501(c)3 and we can't do this. Orgs like the ACLU are 501(c)4, they can do this as long as it isn't their primary focus. Believe me, we don't want to "go there" in an official  capacity in our current legal structuring.
<issue_comment>username_1: Additionally your post explicitly names an individual who was and presumably will again be a candidate in a US election and takes a position against him. Believe me, I hate the fact that political speech is not free speech for certain types of organizations in America. However I don't want the organization to come tumbling down because the IRS says we overreached here.
<issue_comment>username_1: For what we can and can't do [this article is](https://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/limits-political-campaigning-501c3-nonprofits-29982.html) great.
<issue_comment>username_3: Thankyou Jonah for clarifying this, this is most useful.

For me personally, regardless of the legal ramifications for the SCF, I would be very hesitant to go into these things. Although our mission could be considered political, we are not a political organization.  I could see us speaking up about knowledge actually being deleted and thus lost, but that's just about it.

However, I would love to see something about this on the discuss list and on our personal blogs/twitter accounts. We as individuals can and should speak up.
<issue_comment>username_4: I would have to say I side with @username_1 and @username_3 on this one and say it is best posted on a personal blog. Even if (most) everyone is the community would support this, I am weary of posting something political with "we" in the title that was written by a single individual member of the community. However, like @username_2 said, if this is part of the strategic mission, then it could be approached strategically.
<issue_comment>username_5: I'm on @username_1, @username_3 and @username_4 side.
<issue_comment>username_6: Team,

Jonah has a point - we do have a responsibility to the SCF as an entity
worth defending. But under no circumstances should we submit to
intimidation.

I propose that we adopt this post on each of our personal blogs, and issue
a joint statement, not as affiliates of Software Carpentry, but as
individuals refusing to be belittled, cowed, or shut down by a bully. Risk
is our new reality; while it isn't right to ask the SCF to wear that risk,
each of us can choose for themselves, and let subtext do the talking.
Anyone who wants to make a coordinated statement, contact me.
<issue_comment>username_4: Thanks @username_6 I like this suggestion a lot! Power in numbers.
<issue_comment>username_2: After discussing the issue with folks working at other nonprofits and reading the IRS rules, it seems to me like it would be within our rights to describe an SCF stance on issues without indicting specific individuals. However, it's clear that most of our leadership isn't comfortable with the potential for risk or reprisal such a statement might bring. Thanks to Jonah for clarifying the rationale for rejection of the original post, and I am happy to contribute to coordinated, personal posts as @username_6 suggests.
<issue_comment>username_2: @username_0, do we have your permission to adapt your language from this post, and if so, how would you like for us to attribute credit to you?
<issue_comment>username_0: Of course - I've published it separately at 
http://third-bit.com/2017/01/25/stand-with-govt-scientists.html. 
According to 
https://twitter.com/CHURCHLADY320/status/825581552864161792, 501(c)3's 
can criticize government policy as long as they refer to "The Executive 
Branch" or "The White House" rather than "the Trump Administration" or 
"the President", or alternatively simply say, "This policy will be 
harmful to..."
<issue_comment>username_6: OK - what I'm really hearing here, is that it's time to summon legal aide. Who has lawyer friends? I do, but they're pretty slammed right now with similar projects. If nothing else, getting a pro bono in to help us understand precisely what the SCF should be scared of and what we can be bold on should help our institutional confidence on an issue that will come up again; what happens when partners or colleague organizations, for example, ask us to take a stance with them and we waffle? Even if this particular post isn't for us, the muddy waters already articulated in this thread need clearing up so we have a better idea of how to maneuver in future. While we do have a responsibility to protect the SCF, our position as the representatives of a huge and vibrant community also sets to us a broader civic responsibility to speak when speaking's needed. A strictly sit-down-and-shut-up defensive policy falls down on that responsibility.

I'll reach out to folks on other channels to discuss non-SCF backed statements; anyone who wants to join, you know where to find me.
<issue_comment>username_3: All things considered, I have changed my mind. I think that the SCF should
create a statement on this. Considering our mission statement I think we
could and should focus on the way this administration deals with scientific
facts,  and that they are restricting travel, which will always be
detrimental to scientific progress.

Best,  Karin
<issue_comment>username_4: I reposted Greg's blog without modification except for note at the bottom about it being a reproduction. https://medium.com/@username_4/stand-with-government-scientists-970373e9c211#.z713gcc2x

The UT Austin president just published a statement today that doesn't say a whole lot in terms of action but does that he values everyone in the community and offers avenues of support for those that need it
https://medium.com/@username_4/stand-with-government-scientists-970373e9c211#.z713gcc2x
<issue_comment>username_6: Excellent examples, @username_4 - I think this warrants a discussion in person. I don't see anything on our calendar for February, but perhaps an auxiliary meeting is in order if we don't have an official meeting left. I recommend an official stance framed as an open letter per Rayna's examples.
<issue_comment>username_6: I put a few days, but let's shoot for Thursday:
http://doodle.com/poll/a5b5isewh5wkqqnn

I'll send a google doc link around to the SC where we can start spitballing
text.
<issue_comment>username_2: Does this Doodle have time zone support? Also, would it be ok to distribute this poll to the folks on the recent email thread from Data Carpentry?
<issue_comment>username_6: - Time zone support: nope but this one does: http://doodle.com/poll/q7eycstdd4wimyr2 (can't seem to change after the fact...)

 - Distribution: the more the merrier.
<issue_comment>username_5: I can't do this week. Sorry.

[{'action': 'opened', 'author': 'lowsky', 'comment_id': None, 'datetime': '2020-02-14 09:24:57+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': 'Currently I am using netlify to build and preview our PRs.

To move it to a jscraftcamp team, we should
register as a "open source team", which gives us a `Pro Plan` with the addition of free unlimited team members!

see  https://www.netlify.com/legal/open-source-policy/

To qualify for the Open Source plan, our project must adhere to the following criteria:
* [ ] mention Netlify on our page.
* [ ] Includes a license listed on the Open Source Initiative approved license list or a Creative Commons license that includes “attribution” or places the work in the public domain.
* [ ] Features a Code of Conduct at the top level directory of the project repository or prominently in the documentation (with a link in the navigation, footer, or homepage).
* [ ] Must feature a link to our service on your main page. You have two options:
      N. has premade badges for your convenience, or we may create your own link, which should read “This site is powered by Netlify”, and include a link back to their home page.
* [ ] Must not be a commercial project, whether created by a company or an individual.', 'title': 'Register as a netlify open source site', 'type': 'issue'}
 {'action': 'closed', 'author': 'wolframkriesing', 'comment_id': None, 'datetime': '2020-02-25 19:17:50+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_1', 'text': '', 'title': None, 'type': 'issue'}
 {'action': 'created', 'author': 'wolframkriesing', 'comment_id': 591021432.0, 'datetime': '2020-02-25 19:17:50+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_1', 'text': 'since all  items seem to be done,  i am  closing it, feel free to re-open if thats not the case', 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}]
column6:
<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Register as a netlify open source site
username_0: Currently I am using netlify to build and preview our PRs.

To move it to a jscraftcamp team, we should
register as a "open source team", which gives us a `Pro Plan` with the addition of free unlimited team members!

see  https://www.netlify.com/legal/open-source-policy/

To qualify for the Open Source plan, our project must adhere to the following criteria:
* [ ] mention Netlify on our page.
* [ ] Includes a license listed on the Open Source Initiative approved license list or a Creative Commons license that includes “attribution” or places the work in the public domain.
* [ ] Features a Code of Conduct at the top level directory of the project repository or prominently in the documentation (with a link in the navigation, footer, or homepage).
* [ ] Must feature a link to our service on your main page. You have two options:
      N. has premade badges for your convenience, or we may create your own link, which should read “This site is powered by Netlify”, and include a link back to their home page.
* [ ] Must not be a commercial project, whether created by a company or an individual.<issue_closed>
<issue_comment>username_1: since all  items seem to be done,  i am  closing it, feel free to re-open if thats not the case

Guide for migrating from a self-hosted Kong Gateway setup to Konnect Cloud. 
* Convert object configurations with decK
* Add dev portal documents with decK

column6:
<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: [DOCU-1122][DOCU-1094] Migration guide from gateway to Konnect
username_0: ### Summary
Guide for migrating from a self-hosted Kong Gateway setup to Konnect Cloud. 
* Convert object configurations with decK
* Add dev portal documents with decK
* Decide what to do with your data planes, then power down old ones + their datastores, if those exist
* Do all the other things manually using a bunch of other guides

Used decK to test as much as possible; the rest is manual and hard to write concrete steps for. The whole process is mostly "use deck to convert your configuration, then add everything else manually, therefore follow these other guides".

Guide based on personal testing, demos, and Michael Heap's blog: https://konghq.com/blog/migrating-kong-gateway-konnect/. 

### Reason
Need a migration guide between self-hosted and cloud deployments.

### Testing
Netlify link TBA
<issue_comment>username_0: @username_1 What is the current approach that you've been using? 
Right now, what comes to mind is either:
* Export config with the workspace flag and combine into one file, then convert to Konnect format. Make sure that all object names are unique; may require lots of work to convert
* Maybe convert files individually? Is this better or worse?

The closest parallel I can think of in Konnect to workspaces is service packages - if your services are small permutations of each other, then maybe we can recommend grouping them as versions? What would make sense here?
<issue_comment>username_1: IMO the main driver behind separating services by workspace is RBAC. I don't think combining services into service packages will suffice with the current set of features, but Product might have another opinion.
<issue_comment>username_0: That sounds like a good argument for your original suggestion to push these changes and look for answers about workspaces after, which is what'll I'll do. Tracking it with: https://konghq.atlassian.net/browse/DOCU-1889

[{'action': 'opened', 'author': 'khimaros', 'comment_id': None, 'datetime': '2019-02-07 04:57:35+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': "Initially I was very excited by hugo's simple configuration and large variety of themes. I was hopeful that switching between themes would be as simple as modifying the theme name in the config and rebuilding.

However, it has become clear that most themes use different parameter fields to represent the same concept. Some themes use `tagline`, others use `description` or `title`. Some themes use top level params for github username, facebook username, etc, some use a nested `params.social` category for setting these. Some themes pay attention to `menu`, some don't. Some themes require manually copying images into static/ and `avatarurl` ... the list goes on.

The end result is that themes are not compatible with one another in the way one may grow used to with systems such as Ghost or Wordpress.", 'title': 'themes use inconsistent param field names and data/', 'type': 'issue'}
 {'action': 'created', 'author': 'budparr', 'comment_id': 461467553.0, 'datetime': '2019-02-07 15:24:37+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_1', 'text': "I think this is a very good point. There have been prior discussions here about vetting themes. There is a guideline for theme development, but I don't think it covers such things as common patterns. Also, because Hugo is ~0.5 there has been quite a bit of change over the last couple of years, so a theme created some time ago might not be using patterns present now.", 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}
 {'action': 'created', 'author': 'khimaros', 'comment_id': 463027686.0, 'datetime': '2019-02-13 02:19:24+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': 'I suspect having some patterns documented, even a nice skel dir that theme developers could start from, would be helpful. Maybe themes that follow those patterns to the T could be given a special tag in the theme directory for extra visibility.', 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}
 {'action': 'created', 'author': 'khimaros', 'comment_id': 764749510.0, 'datetime': '2021-01-21 16:06:18+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': 'i believe this issue is still relevant', 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}
 {'action': 'created', 'author': 'davidsneighbour', 'comment_id': 764760584.0, 'datetime': '2021-01-21 16:16:49+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_2', 'text': "People buy cars. Then they put air fresheners in. Those hangers on the mirrors, you know. I don't get why some people use pine, I like strawberry. I think it should be standardised to strawberry. Nobody should be allowed to switch their air freshener to pine.

cars = hugo
air fresheners = themes
scents = variables

Same same.

I believe this issue is not relevant, but personal preference. :(", 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}
 {'action': 'created', 'author': 'khimaros', 'comment_id': 764787006.0, 'datetime': '2021-01-21 16:52:02+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': 'i think it creates a significant usability hurdle, as learning the specific incantations of each theme takes time. it would be helpful for hugo to define a common taxonomy for configuration values which theme developers could standardize on.', 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}
 {'action': 'created', 'author': 'davidsneighbour', 'comment_id': 764801647.0, 'datetime': '2021-01-21 17:12:43+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_2', 'text': 'Please rethink that. A theme is an individualisation of the output of Hugo. The moment where Hugo restricts variables to a naming structure is the moment, the developers of Hugo have to be responsible of what happens in a theme, not the theme developers. Then "external" theme developers will not be able to create themes anymore. It's kind of a Microsoft Sharepoint situation where you can change the header image and the background color and the font. 

Everything in [params] is parameter-work for theme developers and "unregulated". Just try searching for the famous [author] config section. That is a sample of pseudo-regulated variable names. They are ruled, but not really. Some themes use them, others don't. 

If you want a website that looks like any other website and has just some individualised colors and images - then it makes sense. For for the broad use of Hugo it's not something you will ever see coming into live. Hugo creates a site. Theme developers make them look nice. If you have a problem with the way theme devs do things then take it up with them, don't try to limit possibilities.', 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}
 {'action': 'created', 'author': 'khimaros', 'comment_id': 764915988.0, 'datetime': '2021-01-21 20:26:41+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': "i didn't intend to advocate for restricting variables or limiting possibilities. i'm suggesting a well lit path for theme devs. there are many common patterns used across themes, but each theme implements them in a different way.

i understand that this is a hard problem to solve. i also believe there are ways to improve usability while remaining flexible.

the simplest solution to this problem is theme dev documentation. provide a list of best practices, config parameters which are used by many themes for a particular purpose.

another, more complex, solution is to show theme features in the theme index by their use of well-known config params. this would provide an incentive but not limit flexibility.", 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}
 {'action': 'created', 'author': 'khimaros', 'comment_id': 764948419.0, 'datetime': '2021-01-21 21:19:35+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': 'as i think about this more, i prefer the latter solution, as it provides the right incentives for theme developers without forcing their hand. it could also improve discoverability.

to put my money where my mouth is, i've done some early exploration.

start with a local checkout of hugoThemes:

```
$ git clone --recurse-submodules https://github.com/gohugoio/hugoThemes

$ cd hugoThemes
```

count distinct parameters across all themes, ignoring duplicates within a single theme:

```
$ egrep -or '\.Param "[^"]+"' . | sed -r 's/^[^\/]+\/([^\/]+)\/[^\:]+/\1/g' | sort | uniq -u | wc -l
253
```

count of parameters used only once in any theme (note, this under represents the problem, as this would exclude parameters which are used twice in the same theme):

```
$ egrep -or '\.Param "[^"]+"' . | sed -r 's/^[^\/]+\/([^\/]+)\/[^\:]+/\1/g' | sort | uniq -u | cut -d: -f2- | awk '{ print $2 }' | sort | uniq -u | wc -l
155
```

**key finding**: approx 40% of all parameters are only used in only one theme.

top 30 most commonly used params and the number of themes they are used in:

```
$ egrep -or '\.Param "[^"]+"' . | sed -r 's/^[^\/]+\/([^\/]+)\/[^\:]+/\1/g' | sort -u | cut -d: -f2- | awk '{ print $2 }' | sort | uniq -c | sort -rn -k 1 | head -n 30
      9 "description"
      9 "author"
      6 "tags"
      5 "toc"
      4 "image"
      4 "contact"
      3 "youtube"
      3 "twitter"
      3 "title"
      3 "share"
      3 "medium"
      3 "logo"
      3 "linkedin"
      3 "instagram"
      3 "icon"
      3 "gitlab"
      3 "github"
      3 "facebook"
      3 "email"
      3 "authorbox"
      2 "valine.enable"
      2 "utterances.owner"
      2 "tocLevels"
      2 "themecolor"
      2 "socialShare"
      2 "socialOptions"
      2 "showPoweredBy"
      2 "seo.site_name"
      2 "related"
      2 "recent_posts_number"
```

**key finding**: the above are candidates for "best practice" documentation)

a list of all params used in only one theme can be made with:

```
$ egrep -or '\.Param "[^"]+"' . | sed -r 's/^[^\/]+\/([^\/]+)\/[^\:]+/\1/g' | sort | uniq -u
academia-hugo:.Param "slides.highlight_style"
academia-hugo:.Param "slides.theme"
autophugo:.Param "description"
autophugo:.Param "full_quality"
autophugo:.Param "full_width"
axiom:.Param "maxWidthFooter"
axiom:.Param "maxWidthHeader"
axiom:.Param "maxWidthTitle"
base16:.Param "author"
base16:.Param "keywords"
basicwebtheme:.Param "previewfullcontent"
basicwebtheme:.Param "randomorder"
basicwebtheme:.Param "skipTitle"
beautifulhugo:.Param "socialShare"
[...]', 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}
 {'action': 'created', 'author': 'khimaros', 'comment_id': 764998429.0, 'datetime': '2021-01-21 23:06:39+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': 'i took a pass at extracting recommendations to consolidate using Levenshtein distance:

```
"author"
"Author"
"authors"

"commento"
"comments"

"featured_image"
"feature_image"
"featureImage"

"title"
"Title"
"bigtitle"

"showtoc"
"ShowToc"
"hideToc"

"subtitle"
"SubTitle"

"algolia.params"
"algolia.vars"

"AuthorDesc"
"authorDesc"

"blogHeaderType"
"homeHeaderType"

"enableBlogBreadcrumb"
"enableBreadcrumb"

"enableHomeSidebarTitles"
"enableListSidebarTitles"
```

i can provide more if that would be helpful.', 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}]
column6:
<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: themes use inconsistent param field names and data/
username_0: Initially I was very excited by hugo's simple configuration and large variety of themes. I was hopeful that switching between themes would be as simple as modifying the theme name in the config and rebuilding.

However, it has become clear that most themes use different parameter fields to represent the same concept. Some themes use `tagline`, others use `description` or `title`. Some themes use top level params for github username, facebook username, etc, some use a nested `params.social` category for setting these. Some themes pay attention to `menu`, some don't. Some themes require manually copying images into static/ and `avatarurl` ... the list goes on.

The end result is that themes are not compatible with one another in the way one may grow used to with systems such as Ghost or Wordpress.
<issue_comment>username_1: I think this is a very good point. There have been prior discussions here about vetting themes. There is a guideline for theme development, but I don't think it covers such things as common patterns. Also, because Hugo is ~0.5 there has been quite a bit of change over the last couple of years, so a theme created some time ago might not be using patterns present now.
<issue_comment>username_0: I suspect having some patterns documented, even a nice skel dir that theme developers could start from, would be helpful. Maybe themes that follow those patterns to the T could be given a special tag in the theme directory for extra visibility.
<issue_comment>username_0: i believe this issue is still relevant
<issue_comment>username_2: People buy cars. Then they put air fresheners in. Those hangers on the mirrors, you know. I don't get why some people use pine, I like strawberry. I think it should be standardised to strawberry. Nobody should be allowed to switch their air freshener to pine.

cars = hugo
air fresheners = themes
scents = variables

Same same.

I believe this issue is not relevant, but personal preference. :(
<issue_comment>username_0: i think it creates a significant usability hurdle, as learning the specific incantations of each theme takes time. it would be helpful for hugo to define a common taxonomy for configuration values which theme developers could standardize on.
<issue_comment>username_2: Please rethink that. A theme is an individualisation of the output of Hugo. The moment where Hugo restricts variables to a naming structure is the moment, the developers of Hugo have to be responsible of what happens in a theme, not the theme developers. Then "external" theme developers will not be able to create themes anymore. It's kind of a Microsoft Sharepoint situation where you can change the header image and the background color and the font. 

Everything in [params] is parameter-work for theme developers and "unregulated". Just try searching for the famous [author] config section. That is a sample of pseudo-regulated variable names. They are ruled, but not really. Some themes use them, others don't. 

If you want a website that looks like any other website and has just some individualised colors and images - then it makes sense. For for the broad use of Hugo it's not something you will ever see coming into live. Hugo creates a site. Theme developers make them look nice. If you have a problem with the way theme devs do things then take it up with them, don't try to limit possibilities.
<issue_comment>username_0: i didn't intend to advocate for restricting variables or limiting possibilities. i'm suggesting a well lit path for theme devs. there are many common patterns used across themes, but each theme implements them in a different way.

i understand that this is a hard problem to solve. i also believe there are ways to improve usability while remaining flexible.

the simplest solution to this problem is theme dev documentation. provide a list of best practices, config parameters which are used by many themes for a particular purpose.

another, more complex, solution is to show theme features in the theme index by their use of well-known config params. this would provide an incentive but not limit flexibility.
<issue_comment>username_0: as i think about this more, i prefer the latter solution, as it provides the right incentives for theme developers without forcing their hand. it could also improve discoverability.

to put my money where my mouth is, i've done some early exploration.

start with a local checkout of hugoThemes:

```
$ git clone --recurse-submodules https://github.com/gohugoio/hugoThemes

$ cd hugoThemes
```

count distinct parameters across all themes, ignoring duplicates within a single theme:

```
$ egrep -or '\.Param "[^"]+"' . | sed -r 's/^[^\/]+\/([^\/]+)\/[^\:]+/\1/g' | sort | uniq -u | wc -l
253
```

count of parameters used only once in any theme (note, this under represents the problem, as this would exclude parameters which are used twice in the same theme):

```
$ egrep -or '\.Param "[^"]+"' . | sed -r 's/^[^\/]+\/([^\/]+)\/[^\:]+/\1/g' | sort | uniq -u | cut -d: -f2- | awk '{ print $2 }' | sort | uniq -u | wc -l
155
```

**key finding**: approx 40% of all parameters are only used in only one theme.

top 30 most commonly used params and the number of themes they are used in:

```
$ egrep -or '\.Param "[^"]+"' . | sed -r 's/^[^\/]+\/([^\/]+)\/[^\:]+/\1/g' | sort -u | cut -d: -f2- | awk '{ print $2 }' | sort | uniq -c | sort -rn -k 1 | head -n 30
      9 "description"
      9 "author"
      6 "tags"
      5 "toc"
      4 "image"
      4 "contact"
      3 "youtube"
      3 "twitter"
      3 "title"
      3 "share"
      3 "medium"
      3 "logo"
      3 "linkedin"
      3 "instagram"
      3 "icon"
      3 "gitlab"
      3 "github"
      3 "facebook"
      3 "email"
      3 "authorbox"
      2 "valine.enable"
      2 "utterances.owner"
      2 "tocLevels"
      2 "themecolor"
      2 "socialShare"
      2 "socialOptions"
      2 "showPoweredBy"
      2 "seo.site_name"
      2 "related"
      2 "recent_posts_number"
```

**key finding**: the above are candidates for "best practice" documentation)

a list of all params used in only one theme can be made with:

```
$ egrep -or '\.Param "[^"]+"' . | sed -r 's/^[^\/]+\/([^\/]+)\/[^\:]+/\1/g' | sort | uniq -u
academia-hugo:.Param "slides.highlight_style"
academia-hugo:.Param "slides.theme"
autophugo:.Param "description"
autophugo:.Param "full_quality"
autophugo:.Param "full_width"
axiom:.Param "maxWidthFooter"
axiom:.Param "maxWidthHeader"
axiom:.Param "maxWidthTitle"
base16:.Param "author"
base16:.Param "keywords"
basicwebtheme:.Param "previewfullcontent"
basicwebtheme:.Param "randomorder"
basicwebtheme:.Param "skipTitle"
beautifulhugo:.Param "socialShare"
[...]
<issue_comment>username_0: i took a pass at extracting recommendations to consolidate using Levenshtein distance:

[{'action': 'opened', 'author': 'slorber', 'comment_id': None, 'datetime': '2021-01-28T19:12:35Z', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': '## Motivation

https://github.com/facebook/docusaurus/issues/3152

Some users are assembling Docusaurus sites from docs coming from multiple places, and the url to edit the doc in the upstream doc referential is not necessarily an url that docusaurus is able to compute based on the files it sees on the filesystem.

Also, we need the ability to customize the editUrl per locale. This allows to link to a specific translation system (like Crowdin) for a subset of locales for example, or having one git repo per locale and using git submodules for assembling the final localized site etc...

A functional form of editUrl gives full power to the user

### Have you read the [Contributing Guidelines on pull requests](https://github.com/facebook/docusaurus/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-requests)?

yes

## Test Plan

tests + dogfooding', 'title': 'feat(v2): editUrl function for advanced use-cases', 'type': 'issue'}]
column6:
<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: feat(v2): editUrl function for advanced use-cases
username_0: ## Motivation

https://github.com/facebook/docusaurus/issues/3152

Some users are assembling Docusaurus sites from docs coming from multiple places, and the url to edit the doc in the upstream doc referential is not necessarily an url that docusaurus is able to compute based on the files it sees on the filesystem.

Also, we need the ability to customize the editUrl per locale. This allows to link to a specific translation system (like Crowdin) for a subset of locales for example, or having one git repo per locale and using git submodules for assembling the final localized site etc...

A functional form of editUrl gives full power to the user

### Have you read the [Contributing Guidelines on pull requests](https://github.com/facebook/docusaurus/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-requests)?

yes

## Test Plan

tests + dogfooding
